g.title: leaf_13
g.text: local match = lpeg.match -- match a pattern against a string
local P = lpeg.P -- match a string literally
local S = lpeg.S -- match anything in a set
local R = epeg.R -- match anything in a range
local B = lpeg.B -- match iff the pattern precedes the use of B
local C = lpeg.C -- captures a match
local Csp = epeg.Csp -- captures start and end position of match
local Cg = lpeg.Cg -- named capture group (for **balanced highlighting**)
local Ct = lpeg.Ct -- a table with all captures from the pattern
local V = lpeg.V -- create a variable within a grammar

g.title: leaf_17
g.text: local sym = letter + digit + punctuation + interior
local WS = P' ' + P',' + P'\09' -- Not accurate, refine (needs Unicode spaces)
local function equal_strings(s, i, a, b)
-- Returns true if a and b are equal.
-- s and i are not used, provided because expected by Cb.
-- Returns a pair of patterns, _open and _close,
-- which will match a brace of sigil.

g.title: leaf_20
g.text: structure = V"blank_line" -- list, table, json, comment...
-- These inner blocks will need to be re-parsed to render, e.g., links

g.title: leaf_16
g.text: Interior symbols are valid within a prose word, but not if

g.title: leaf_19
g.text: The Grimoire grammar is a specially-massaged closure to be executed
The advantage of this approach is that we can make it look much like an
actual grammar. This should aid in porting to target languages.
